title: Should I credit the author of a free design if I want to use it for personal reasons? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here’s the thing. The site says you must credit the Author and that’s cool. The Author is giving away his creation for the small cost of including their name in a small print line that pretty much everyone ignores even in store bought cards. They’re not asking you to include the Author’s name spread across a whole side of the card like a book title. BUT! (Yep, there’s a “but”) It seems you’re only making one of these and pretty much the only person who’ll get to see it is your friend. Store bought or not your friend would have most probably concentrated in your best wishes and ignored this small print crediting the Author so as long as you’re not planing on printing a run of these and selling them, no matter how cheap, its okay to skip crediting the author. Tho as a designer myself, even if i know the line would be mostly ignored, it’d still be nice to be credited. After all, you considered this Authors work worthy enough to hold your Birthday wishes for your friend so he must have done something right and all he asks is for a little love in a tiny line.

If it says to acknowledge source, then you should. Perhaps you can change the design a little and hand color it, then you can say that the image was adapted from an original design by __________. It’s always ethical to acknowledge the source. If this is a friend, s/he should appreciate the gesture and not worry about where the original design began. But why not create your own design? and then there is no problem.

Why will it look bad to your friend? Unless you want to show of….? Mention the credits in small print on the back: Inspired by the work of …. Just do it, as it is the right thing to do for a fellow human being. Honesty towords a friend goes further than vanity. Use your imagination / writing to add a personal quote for your friend.
It's okay if you don't include the authors name for personal use. But in case you are using it for commercial purpose, then you should.
Maybe put the attribution in tiny letters on the back? Given it’s just for one person, as opposed to national publication, as long as you don’t claim it’s your own work I’m not sure it matters.
